Enhanced Resolution Cameras
Amateur Radio | programme = [[Philippine Scientific Earth Observation Microsatellite program]] | previous_mission = [[Maya-1]] | next_mission = | insignia = | insignia_caption = | insignia_alt = | insignia_size = }} {{Use mdy|date=October 2018}}'''Diwata-2''' or '''Diwata-2B'''{{cite web |title=Live coverage: Japan’s H-2A rocket poised for 40th flight |url=https://spaceflightnow.com/2018/10/28/h-2a-f40-mission-status-center/ |website=SpaceFlight Now |accessdate=29 October 2018 |date=28 October 2018}} is a Philippine microsatellite launched in October 29, 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.flipscience.ph/news/pinoy-made-diwata-2-microsatellite-scheduled-for-launch/|title=Diwata-2 microsatellite scheduled for October 29 launch|date=2018-10-28|work=FlipScience|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://technology.inquirer.net/80735/ph-successfully-sends-diwata2-microsatellite-into-space|title=PH successfully sends Diwata-2 microsatellite into space|last=Cabalza|first=Dexter|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.rappler.com/science-nature/earth-space/215468-philippine-made-microsatellite-diwata-2-space-launch-october-29-2018|title=PH-made microsatellite Diwata-2 flies into space|work=Rappler|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://leagueonlinenews.com/news/dost-to-launch-diwata-2-micro-satellite-on-oct-29/|title=DOST TO LAUNCH DIWATA-2 MICRO SATELLITE ON OCT. 29|work=League Online News|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}} It is the second satellite of the [[Philippine Scientific Earth Observation Microsatellite program|Philippine Scientific Earth Observation Microsatellite (PHL-Microsat)]] program after [[Diwata-1]]. ==Development== The satellite was developed by 11 scholars under the Philippine [[Department of Science and Technology (Philippines)|Department of Science and Technology]] (DOST), in cooperation with the [[Tohoku University]] and [[Hokkaido University]] in contrast to 9 DOST scholars who worked with [[Diwata-1]], Diwata-2's predecessor.{{cite news|last1=Mondonedo-Ynot|first1=Laureen|title=Diwata 2's payload includes amateur radio|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2017/01/18/diwata-2s-payload-includes-amateur-radio-520807|accessdate=25 January 2017|work=Sun Star Manila|date=18 January 2017}} Unlike its predecessor, Diwata-2 takes advantage of radio communication technology by carrying an amateur radio payload for disaster relief purposes. The satellite also hosts all embedded features of its predecessor.{{cite news|url=http://davaotoday.com/main/headline/change-is-coming-how-space-technology-is-changing-disaster-risk-management-in-phl/|title=Change is coming (1/2): How space technology is changing disaster risk management in PHL|last1=Sambalud|first1=Mark|date=7 December 2016|work=Davao Today|accessdate=25 January 2017}} The planning phase of the Diwata-2's development includes a simulation model, a mechanical test model, an engineering model and a flight model. This stage ended with the flight model which was completed on August 29, 2018 and was handed over to the [[Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency]] (JAXA) on the following day.{{cite news |title=Diwata-2 microsatellite launching on Oct. 29 |url=https://businessmirror.com.ph/diwata-2-microsatellite-launching-on-oct-29/ |accessdate=28 October 2018 |work=BusinessMirror |date=28 October 2018}} ==Instruments== Weighing {{convert|56|kg|lb|abbr=on}}, Diwata-2 will host an amateur radio payload which will enable people in the Philippines to relay messages through ham radio to any part of the country. This function is meant for disaster relief operations. The satellite will also carry Spaceborne Multispectral Imager (SMI) with liquid crystal tunable filter (LCTF) for environmental monitoring, and a high precision telescope (HPT) for rapid post-disaster assessment. Compared to Diwata-1 which hosted wide and middle field cameras, Diwata-2 will host enhanced resolution cameras. The SMI, is equipped with an upgraded enhanced spatial resolution camera allowing the satellite to produced sharper images than the Diwata-1. It will also have a deployable solar panels to power the satellite's payloads.{{cite news |last1=Tumampos |first1=Stephanie |last2=Resurreccion |first2=Lyn |title=PHL flying high–into space |url=https://businessmirror.com.ph/phl-flying-high-into-space/ |accessdate=29 October 2018 |work=BusinessMirror |date=29 October 2018}} ==Launch and mission== The satellite was targeted by the DOST to be deployed as early as the second quarter of 2018.{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/technology/features/171988-diwata-1-diwata-2-improvements-up-tech-fair|title=How Diwata-2 is better than PH's first satellite, Diwata-1|last1=Usman|first1=Edd|date=5 June 2017|work=Rappler|accessdate=6 June 2017}} The projected launch date was later adjusted at least twice; June 2018{{cite news |last1=Yee |first1=Jovic |title=Pinoy students fail to reach astronauts at space station |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/969721/pinoy-students-fail-to-reach-astronauts-at-space-station |accessdate=2 June 2018 |work=Philippine Daily Inquirer |date=19 February 2018}} and later pushed forward to fourth quarter of 2018.{{cite news |last1=Reyes |first1=Rizal Raoul |title=Russia’s elite space program opens doors to Filipino scholar |url=https://businessmirror.com.ph/russias-elite-space-program-opens-doors-to-filipino-scholar/ |accessdate=15 October 2018 |date=23 September 2018 |quote=Diwata 2 is expected to be launched in the last quarter of this year.}} It was announced that on October 26, 2018 the satellite would be launched to space via the [[H-IIA]] from Japan{{cite news |title=DOST to launch microsatellite to gather data on disasters |url=https://www.ptvnews.ph/dost-to-launch-microsatellite-to-gather-data-on-disasters/ |accessdate=27 October 2018 |work=PTV News |date=27 October 2018}} at the [[Tanegashima Space Center]] at around 13:08 and 13:20 ([[Japan Standard Time|JST]]). Unlike [[Diwata-1]], Diwata-2 will be directly deployed from the rocket that will carry it from space and not from the [[International Space Station]] like its predecessor. The satellite, which will piggyback on the bigger Japanese satellite [[Greenhouse Gases Observing Satellite|Gosat-2]] will be propelled to an elevation of {{convert|620|km|mi|abbr=on}} above sea level. On October 29, 2018, the satellite was launched directly into orbit at 13:51 ([[UTC+9]]).{{cite news |last1=Panela |first1=Shaira |title=PH-made microsatellite Diwata-2 flies into space |url=https://www.rappler.com/science-nature/earth-space/215468-philippine-made-microsatellite-diwata-2-space-launch-october-29-2018 |accessdate=29 October 2018 |work=Rappler |date=29 October 2018}} Communication between the satellite and the DOST-ASTI's ground station in Quezon City was first established on October 29 at 21:52 ([[UTC+8]]).{{cite news |last1=Resurreccion |first1=Lyn |title=Diwata-2 makes first contact with receiving station in PHL |url=https://businessmirror.com.ph/diwata-2-makes-first-contact-with-receiving-station-in-phl/ |accessdate=2 November 2018 |work=BusinessMirror |date=1 November 2018}} Diwata-2 will have the same mission as its predecessor, [[Diwata-1]]. It will have a [[Sun-synchronous orbit|sun-synchronous orbit]] having been equip with an experimental sun sensor which would allow the operators to determine the position of the satellite in respective to the sun and it will orbit at an altitude of {{convert|620|km|mi|abbr=on}} above sea level. It will also have a fixed visit interval time unlike its predecessor, meaning it will hover above the same position on Earth for every 16 days. The satellite has a projected life expectancy of five years. ==See also== *[[Agila-2]] *[[Space program of the Philippines]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Philippine space program}} {{Orbital launches in 2018}} [[Category:Communications satellites]] [[Category:Earth observation satellites]] [[Category:Satellites of the Philippines]] [[Category:2018 in the Philippines]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2018]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by H-II rockets]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/31.167.49.58|31.167.49.58]] ([[User talk:31.167.49.58|talk]]) to last version by CLCStudent
revision.text: {{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[File:Londinio Mogontio.jpg|thumb|A tablet from c. 65 AD, reading "Londinio Mogontio"- "In London, to Mogontius"]] The name of [[London]] is derived from a word first attested, in Latinised form, as ''[[Londinium]]''. By the first century CE, this was a commercial centre in [[Roman Britain]]. The etymology of the name is uncertain. There is a long history of mythicising etymologies, such as the twelfth-century [[Historia Regum Britanniae]] asserting that the city's name is derived from the name of [[Lud son of Heli|King Lud]] who once controlled the city. However, in recent times a variety of alternative theories have also been proposed. As of 2017, the trend in scholarly publications supports derivation from a British Celtic form *[Londonjon], which would itself have been of Celtic origin.Peter Schrijver, [[Language Contact and the Origins of the Germanic Languages]], Routledge Studies in Linguistics, 13 (New York: Routledge, 2014), p. 57.Theodora Bynon, 'London's Name', ''Transactions of the Philological Society'', 114:3 (2016), 281–97, doi: 10.1111/1467-968X.12064. ==Attested forms== [[Richard Coates]], in the 1998 article where he published his own theory of the etymology, lists all the known occurrences of the name up to around the year 900, in [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Latin language|Latin]], [[British language (Celtic)|British]] and [[Anglo-Saxon language|Anglo-Saxon]].{{cite journal|last=Coates|first=Richard|year=1998|title=A new explanation of the name of London|journal=Transactions of the Philological Society|volume=96|issue=2|pages=203–229|url=http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/1467-968X.00027|doi=10.1111/1467-968X.00027}} Most of the older sources begin with ''Londin-'' (Λονδίνιον, ''Londino'', ''[[Londinium]]'' etc.), though there are some in ''Lundin-''. Later examples are mostly ''Lundon-'' or ''London-'', and all the Anglo-Saxon examples have ''Lunden-'' with various terminations. He observes that the modern spelling with <o> derives from a medieval writing habit of avoiding <u> between letters composed of [[minim (palaeography)|minim]]s. The earliest written mention of London occurs in a letter discovered in London in 2016. Dated AD 65–80, it reads ''Londinio Mogontio'' which translates to "In London, to Mogontius".[https://www.archaeology.co.uk/articles/features/earliest-written-reference-to-london-found.htm "Earliest written reference to London found"], on ''Current Archaeology'', 1 June 2016. Retrieved on 26 January 2018.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-36415563 "UK's oldest hand-written document 'at Roman London dig'"], on ''BBC News'', 1 June 2016. Retrieved on 26 January 2018.[https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jun/01/tablets-unearthed-city-glimpse-roman-london-bloomberg "Oldest handwritten documents in UK unearthed in London dig"], in ''The Guardian'', 1 June 2016. Retrieved on 26 January 2018.[https://www.ianvisits.co.uk/blog/2016/06/01/oldest-reference-to-roman-london-found-in-new-tube-station-entrance/ "Oldest reference to Roman London found in new tube station entrance"], on ''IanVisits'', 1 June 2016. Retrieved on 26 January 2018. ==Phonology== Coates (1998) asserts that "It is quite clear that these vowel letters in the earliest forms [viz., ''Londinium'', ''Lundinium''], both <o> and <u>, represent phonemically long vowel sounds". He observes that the ending in Latin sources before 600 is always ''-inium'', which points to a British double termination ''-in-jo-n''. It has long been observed that the Anglo-Saxon form ''Lunden'' and the Welsh name {{lang|cy|Llundein}} cannot be directly derived from [[Common Brittonic]] ''*Londinjon''. Following regular sound changes in the two languages, Welsh would have had *''Lunnen'' or similar, and Old English would have *''Lynden'' via [[I-mutation|''i''-mutation]].Peter Schrijver, ''[[Language Contact and the Origins of the Germanic Languages]]'' (2013), p. 57. Coates (1998) tentatively accepts the argument by Jackson (1938){{cite journal|last=Jackson|first=Kenneth H.|journal=Antiquity|title=Nennius and the 28 cities of Britain|volume=12|pages=44–55|year=1938}} that the British form was ''-on-jo-n'', with the change to ''-inium'' unexplained. Coates speculates further that the first ''-i-'' could have arisen by [[Metathesis (linguistics)|metathesis]] of the ''-i-'' in the last syllable of his own suggested etymon (see below). [[Peter Schrijver]] (2013) by way of explaining the medieval forms ''Lunden'' and ''Llundein'' considers two possibilities: * In the local dialect of Lowland British Celtic, which later became extinct, ''-ond-'' became ''-und-'' regularly, and ''-ī-'' became ''-ei-'', leading to ''Lundeinjon'', later ''Lundein''. The Welsh and English forms were then borrowed from this. This hypothesis requires that the Latin form have a long ''ī'': ''Londīnium''. * The early [[British Latin]] dialect probably developed similarly as the dialect of Gaul (the ancestor of [[Old French]]). In particular, Latin stressed short ''i'' developed first into close-mid {{IPA|/e/}}, then diphthongised to {{IPA|/ei/}}. The combination ''-ond-'' also developed regularly into ''-und-'' in pre-Old French. Thus, he concludes, the remaining Romans of Britain would have pronounced the name as ''Lundeiniu'', later ''Lundein'', from which the Welsh and English forms were then borrowed. This hypothesis requires that the Latin form have a short ''i'': ''Londinium''. Schrijver therefore concludes that the name of ''Londinium'' underwent phonological changes in a local dialect (either British Celtic or British Latin) and that the recorded medieval forms in Welsh and Anglo-Saxon would have been derived from that dialectal pronunciation. ==Proposed etymologies== ===Celtic=== Coates says (p. 211) that "The earliest non-mythic speculation ... centred on the possibility of deriving London from Welsh {{lang|cy|Llyn din}}, supposedly 'lake fort' (? or 'fort lake'). But {{lang|cy|llyn}} derives from British ''*Lind-'', which is incompatible with all the early attestations. Another suggestion, published in ''[[The Geographical Journal]]'' in 1899, is that the area of London was previously settled by [[Belgae]] who named their outposts after townships in [[Belgium]]. Some of these Belgic toponyms have been attributed to the namesake of London including ''[[Limé]]'', ''[[Douvrend]]'', and ''[[Londinières]]''.{{Cite journal | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rDAMAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA299 | work = The Geographical Journal | year = 1899}} [[Marie Henri d'Arbois de Jubainville|H. D'Arbois de Jubainville]] suggested in 1899 that the name meant ''Londino's fortress''.{{cite book|last=D'Arbois de Jubainville|first=H|year=1899|title=La Civilisation des Celtes et celle de l'épopée homérique|publisher=Albert Fontemoing|location=Paris|language=fr}} But Coates argues that there is no such personal name recorded, and that D'Arbois' suggested etymology for it (from Celtic ''*londo-'', 'fierce') would have a short vowel. Coates notes that this theory was repeated by linguistics up to the 1960s, and more recently still in less specialist works. It was revived in 2013 by Peter Schrijver, who suggested that the sense of the proto-Indo-European root *''lendh-'' ('sink, cause to sink'), which gave rise to the Celtic noun *''londos'' ('a subduing'), survived in Celtic. Combined with the Celtic suffix *-''injo''- (used to form singular nouns from collective ones), this could explain a Celtic form *''londinjon'' 'place that floods (periodically, tidally)'. This, in Schrijver's reading, would more readily explain all the Latin, Welsh, and English forms.Peter Schrijver, [[Language Contact and the Origins of the Germanic Languages]], Routledge Studies in Linguistics, 13 (New York: Routledge, 2014), p. 57. Similar approaches to Schrijver's have been taken by [[Theodora Bynon]], who in 2016 supported a similar Celtic etymology, while demonstrating that the place-name was borrowed into the [[West Germanic]] ancestor-language of Old English, not into Old English itself.Theodora Bynon, 'London's Name', ''Transactions of the Philological Society'', 114:3 (2016), 281–97, doi: 10.1111/1467-968X.12064. ===Non-Celtic=== Among the first scientific explanations was one by Giovanni Alessio in 1951.{{cite conference|last=Alessio|first=Giovanni|title=L'origine du nom de Londres|booktitle=Actes et Mémoires du troisième congrès international de toponymie et d'anthroponymie|location=Louvain|publisher=Instituut voor naamkunde|language=fr|year=1951|pages=223–224}} He proposed a [[Ligurian language (ancient)|Ligurian]] rather than a Celtic origin, with a root ''*lond-/lont-'' meaning 'mud' or 'marsh'. Coates' major criticisms are that this does not have the required long vowel (an alternative form Alessio proposes, ''*lōna'', has the long vowel, but lacks the required consonant), and that there is no evidence of Ligurian in Britain. Jean-Gabriel Gigot in a 1974 article discusses the toponym of [[Saint-Martin-de-Londres]], a commune in the French [[Hérault (département)|Hérault département]]. Gigot derives this ''Londres'' from a Germanic root ''*lohna'', and argues that the British toponym may also be from that source.{{cite journal|title=Notes sur le toponyme "Londres" (Hérault)|last=Gigot|first=Jean-Gabriel|journal=Revue international d'onomastique|volume=26|year=1974|pages=284–292}} Coates (1998) proposes a [[Common Brittonic]] form of either ''*Lōondonjon'' or ''*Lōnidonjon'', which would have become ''*Lūndonjon'' and hence ''Lūndein'' or ''Lūndyn''. An advantage of the form ''*Lōnidonjon'' is that it could account for Latin ''Londinium'' by [[Metathesis (linguistics)|metathesis]] to ''*Lōnodinjon''. The etymology of this ''*Lōondonjon'' would however lie in [[pre-Celtic]] [[Old European hydronymy]], from a hydronym ''*Plowonida'', which would have been applied to the Thames where it becomes too wide to ford, in the vicinity of London. The settlement on its banks would then be named from the hydronym with the suffix ''-on-jon'', giving ''*Plowonidonjon'' and [[Insular Celtic]] ''*Lowonidonjon''. The name of the river itself would be derived from the [[Indo-European root]]s ''*plew-'' "to flow, swim; boat" and ''*nejd-'' "to flow", found in various river names around Europe. Coates does admit that compound names are comparatively rare for rivers in the Indo-European area, but they are not entirely unknown. Lacey Wallace describes the derivation as "somewhat tenuous".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gbMkBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA8&lpg=PA8&dq=%22plowonida%22&source=bl&ots=5VMiS5rite&sig=EcOvXFRkzj0qqr7OOnMfrpnbQdQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj1opLGoJ7NAhXoJcAKHQHtDls4ChDoAQgrMAU#v=onepage&q=%22plowonida%22&f=false|first=Lacey|last=Wallace|page=8|title=The Origin of Roman London|year=2015|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location =Cambridge, UK|isbn=9781107047570}} The [[Museum of London]] is more positive, stating on its web site "philologists now equate the name with the Indo-European word 'plowonida', meaning 'fast-flowing river' and referring to the Thames".{{cite web|url=http://archive.museumoflondon.org.uk/MuseumOfLondon/Templates/microsites/londinium/article.aspx?NRMODE=Published&NRNODEGUID=%7B43F5954B-D51C-4FAF-AF8D-63644DECA2D6%7D&NRORIGINALURL=%2FLondinium%2Fanalysis%2Fpubliclife%2Fadministration%2F4%2BLondin.htm&NRCACHEHINT=NoModifyGuest|title=From Londinium to London|publisher=Museum of London|accessdate=10 June 2016}} The display on Roman London in the museum state the etymology as fact. ==Historical and popular suggestions== The earliest account of the toponym's derivation can be attributed to [[Geoffrey of Monmouth]]. In ''[[Historia Regum Britanniae]]'', the name is described as originating from [[Lud son of Heli|King Lud]], who seized the city [[Trinovantum]] and ordered it to be renamed in his honour as ''Kaerlud''. This was then eventually slurred into ''Karelundein'' and then ''London''. However, Geoffrey's work contains many fanciful suppositions about place-name derivation and the suggestion has no basis in linguistics.[http://chr.org.uk/legends.htm Legends of London's Origins] Other fanciful theories over the years have been: * [[William Camden]] reportedly suggested that the name might come from [[Common Brittonic|Brythonic]] ''lhwn'' (modern Welsh {{lang|cy|Llwyn}}), meaning "grove", and "town". Thus, giving the origin as ''Lhwn Town'', translating to "city in the grove".{{Cite journal | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=lqkHAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA4 | title = The history and antiquities of Highgate, Middlesex | author1 = Prickett | first1 = Frederick | year = 1842}} * John Jackson, writing in the ''[[Gentleman's Magazine]]'' in 1792,{{cite journal|last=Jackson|first=John|year=1792|journal=The Gentleman's Magazine|title=Conjecture on the Etymology of London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xj8lAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA453&lpg=PA453&dq=%22etymology+of+london%22|publisher=Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown}} challenges the ''Llyn din'' theory (see below) on geographical grounds, and suggests instead a derivation from {{lang|cy|Glynn din}} – presumably intended as 'valley city'. * Some [[British Israelism|British Israelites]] claimed that the Anglo-Saxons, assumed to be descendants of the [[Tribe of Dan]], named their settlement ''lan-dan'', meaning "abode of Dan" in [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]].{{cite journal|title=English words of supposed Hebrew origin in George Crabb's ''English Synonymes|last=Gold|first=David L|journal=American Speech|year=1979|volume=51|pages=61–64|issue=1|doi=10.2307/454531|jstor=454531|publisher=Duke University Press}} * An unsigned article in ''The Cambro Briton'' for 1821{{cite journal|journal=The Cambro Briton|title=Etymology of 'London'|year=1821|pages=42–43|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tnEEAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA42}} supports the suggestion of ''Luna din'' ('moon fortress'), and also mentions in passing the possibility of ''Llong din'' ('ship fortress'). * Several theories were discussed in the pages of ''[[Notes and Queries]]'' on 27 December 1851,{{Cite journal | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=DuX6reRuEaMC&pg=PA505&lpg=PA505&dq=%22etymology+of+london%22 | title = Notes and Queries | year = 1852}} including ''Luandun'' (supposedly "city of the moon", a reference to the temple of [[Diana (mythology)|Diana]] supposed to have stood on the site of [[St Paul's Cathedral]]), and ''Lan Dian'' or ''Llan Dian'' ("temple of Diana"). Another correspondent dismissed these, and reiterated the common ''Llyn din'' theory. * In ''The Cymry of '76'' (1855),{{cite book|title=The Cymry of '76|last=Jones|first=Alexander|year=1855|publisher=Sheldon, Lamport|location=New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NFLJNoaq4G4C&pg=PA132&lpg=PA132&dq=%22etymology+of+london%22}} Alexander Jones says that the Welsh name derives from ''Llyn Dain'', meaning 'pool of the Thames'. * An 1887 Handbook for Travellers{{cite book|year=1887|title=London and Its Environs: Handbook for Travellers|last=Baedeker|first=Karl|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EawMAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA60|publisher=K. Baedeker}} asserts that "The etymology of London is the same as that of Lincoln" (Latin {{lang|la|Lindum}}). * The general [[Henri Nicolas Frey]], in his 1894 book ''Annamites et extrême-occidentaux: recherches sur l'origine des langues'',{{cite book|title=Annamites et extrême-occidentaux: recherches sur l'origine des langues.|last=Henry|first=Frey|year=1894|publisher=Hachette et Cie|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SxkTAAAAYAAJ}} emphasises the similarity between the name of the city and the two Vietnamese words lœun and dœun which can both mean "low, inferior, muddy". * [[Edward P. Cheney]], in his 1904 book ''A Short History of England'' (p. 18), attributes the origin of the name to [[dun]]: "Elevated and easily defensible spots were chosen [in pre-Roman times], earthworks thrown up, always in a circular form, and palisades placed upon these. Such a fortification was called a dun, and London and the names of many other places still preserve that termination in varying forms." * ''A New Variorum Edition of Shakespeare'' (1918){{cite book|title=A New Variorum Edition of Shakespeare''|year=1918|last=Furness (ed)|first=Horace Howard|publisher=J B Lippincott & co|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3UgvAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA175|isbn=0-486-21187-8}} mentions a variant on Geoffrey's suggestion being ''Lud's town'', although refutes it saying that the origin of the name was most likely [[Old English language|Saxon]]. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Etymology Of London}} [[Category:Culture in London]] [[Category:English toponymy|London]] [[Category:Social history of London]] [[Category:Etymologies of geographic names|London]]

[[Image:Bahrain municipalities numbered.png|right|Map of Bahrain showing municipalities]] '''[[Bahrain]]''' was formerly split into twelve [[regions]] ([[mintaqah]]) that were all administered from the capital city of [[Manama]]. On July 3, 2002, these were superseded by the five [[Governorates of Bahrain]] (four as of September 2014, with the abolishment of the [[Central Governorate, Bahrain|Central Governorate]]).
# [[Al Hadd]] # [[Al Manamah]] # [[Al Mintaqah al Gharbiyah]] (Western) # [[Al Wusta Region (Bahrain)|Al Mintaqah al Wusta]] (Central) # [[Al Mintaqah al Shamaliyah]] (Northern) # [[Al Muharraq]] # [[Ar Rifa' wa al Mintaqah al Janubiyah]] (Rifa and Southern) # [[Jidd Haffs]] # [[Madinat Hamad]] # [[Madinat 'Isa]] # [[Juzur Hawar]] # [[Sitrah]]
The map does not show Madinat Hamad, which was split off from Ar Rifa' wa al Mintaqah al Janubiyah in 1991.
The following map does not show [[Hamad Town]], which was split off from [[Rifa and Southern Region, Bahrain|Rifa and Southern Region]] in 1991.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Map !! Former Municipality |- | rowspan="13" | [[Image:Bahrain municipalities numbered.png|200px]] |- | | '''1.''' [[Al Hidd]] |- | | '''2.''' [[Manama]] |- | | '''3.''' [[Western Region, Bahrain|Western Region]] |- | | '''4.''' [[Central Region, Bahrain|Central Region]] |- | | '''5.''' [[Northern Region, Bahrain|Northern Region]] |- | | '''6.''' [[Muharraq]] |- | | '''7.''' [[Rifa and Southern Region, Bahrain|Rifa and Southern Region]] |- | | '''8.''' [[Jidd Haffs]] |- | | '''9.''' [[Hamad Town]] |- | | '''10.''' [[Isa Town]] |- | | '''11.''' [[Hawar Islands]] |- | | '''12.''' [[Sitra]] |- |}
[[Category:Lists of country subdivisions|Bahrain, Municipalities]] [[Category:Subdivisions of Bahrain]] [[Category:History of Bahrain]] [[Category:Former subdivisions of countries|Bahrain]]
{{Bahrain-geo-stub}}
